org.mitre.provenance.plusobject.builder

Class ProvBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.mitre.provenance.plusobject.ProvenanceCollection
      • org.mitre.provenance.dag.ViewedCollection
        • org.mitre.provenance.plusobject.builder.ProvBuilder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BenchmarkGenerator

    public class ProvBuilder
extends ViewedCollection
    A tool to help build provenance graphs more easily, and to make code to do so more readable. For example, to create a simple two-node graph that shows a data item input to a process, this code can be used: 

    new ProvBuilder().link(db.dataNamed("Data input"), db.invocationNamed("Process Foo"))

    Most types return a ProvBuilder for easy method chaining. Almost all methods do not modify the state of the current object, they return a new object.

    Below is some sample code that illustrates building a simple workflow. Let's say that we want to model two pieces of data ("X" and "Y" with values "3" and "4" respectively) being fed into an "addition" process, resulting in a piece of data "Z" (value 7). That code might look like this: 

      ProvBuilder pb = new ProvBuilder(new PLUSWorkflow("Simple Addition"), null);
  
  ProvBuilder inputs = new ProvBuilder(
     pb.newNodeNamed("X", "value", "3"),
     pb.newNodeNamed("Y", "value", "4"));
     
  ProvBuilder process = pb.newInvocationNamed("Addition");
  ProvBuilder output = pb.newNodeNamed("Z", "value", "7");
  return pb.merge(pb.link(inputs, process), pb.link(process, output));
    A number of methods take an arbitrary number of Strings called "metadataKeyValuePairs". Java doesn't permit static initialization of maps, so this is how some basic metadata can be specified in creating a new object. For example, if you call newDataNamed("Foo", "X", "hello", "Y", "world") then you'll get an object named Foo, with two metadata pairs: X=hello, and Y=world.
    Author:
    moxious

      • excise

        public ProvBuilder excise(ProvBuilder items,
                          boolean removeWorkflows)
        Remove all items found in one builder from this, and returns a new builder. Removes all edges incident to nodes being removed.
        Parameters:
        items - the list of items you want removed
        removeWorkflows - if true, workflow nodes will be removed as well. If false, they won't be.
        Returns:
        new declarative builder

      • mostRecent

        public ProvBuilder mostRecent()
        Find the most recent node (by creation date) and return a new builder containing only that node. If there are no nodes, the result will be empty.
        Returns:
        a ProvBuilder

      • nodeNamed

        public ProvBuilder nodeNamed(String name)
        Find a node with the given name in the current ProvBuilder, and return a new builder containing only that node. If the node cannot be found, the result will be empty. This will return the first result only. So if there is more than one node with the same name, only the first will be returned.
        Parameters:
        name -
        Returns:
        a ProvBuilder containing one or zero nodes.
        See Also:
        nodesMatching(String)
